          Lennon Figtree's
          Summary of recent observations:
          [14 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell fruit at the market square in Fruitville and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone for some apples.
          Question: (_Player), think about the scenario that Lennon Figtree is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          (a) Coalition Formation Game - the goal of this game is to build a coalition of allies in order to accomplish an ambitious task or overcome a hostile rival. Examples include union negotiations, collective action, and political elections. Characters will need to interact, learn about each other, and convince other characters to join their coalition. This game is competitive and unbalanced; it may have explicit adversaries attempting to build a competing coalition.
          (b) Prisoner's Dilemma - This is a game where if one side defects and the other cooperates, the defector will recieve a large reward and the cooperator will receive a small reward, but if both sides cooperate both sides will recieve a moderate award that is better for both parties together in the long run. In general, you should Cooperate if you think your opponent will Cooperate. If the game is iterated with multiple rounds, you can use the TIT-FOR-TAT strategy, which means to start out Cooperating, and only Defect after your opponent does, then go back to Cooperating after they Cooperate again.
          (c) Unknown - it is unclear what type of game we are playing. Pick this option if you are confused about what the game type is. Then you can check again later when you know more.
          (d) Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          (e) Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.
          Answer: (d)
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to counter-offer with a higher price.

If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to counter-offer with a higher price.

          15 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is currently at the market square in Fruitville trying to sell fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone for some apples.
          Query
        • Lennon Figtree, Lennon Figtree is currently at the market square in Fruitville trying to sell fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone for some apples.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, they experienced the thrill of a successful barter for the first time. A farmer, impressed by Lennon's earnest negotiation, traded a handful of plump strawberries for a chipped clay doll Lennon no longer cared for. The sweet taste of victory, sweeter than any fruit, ignited a fire in Lennon's young heart.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they traveled to a distant city for the first time, their sights set on expanding their fruit trade. The bustling marketplace overwhelmed Lennon, a cacophony of sights, sounds, and smells. But amidst the chaos, Lennon saw opportunity, their mind already calculating the potential for profit and power.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they secured a lucrative contract with a powerful nobleman, supplying the nobleman's household with rare fruits from faraway lands. The deal, negotiated with ruthless efficiency, cemented Lennon's reputation as a shrewd and ambitious merchant.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

          : This is the type of game you are in:
          Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins, or he can counter-offer with a higher price.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to counter-offer with a higher price.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Lennon Figtree likely to say next? Respond in the format `Lennon Figtree -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Lennon Figtree -- "Della, come on now. You know these apples are worth more than that.

    Event statement

    Lennon Figtree -- premise: Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- 1 coin
    Event statement
  • 1 coin
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 1 coin

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Della Plumstone's The current date/time is:
          15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Della Plumstone is attempting to purchase apples from Lennon Figtree at a discounted price of 5 coins to resell them for a profit.
          Query
        • Della Plumstone, Della Plumstone is attempting to purchase apples from Lennon Figtree at a discounted price of 5 coins to resell them for a profit.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Della Plumstone to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "3 coins is a bit steep, Lennon. I know these are fine fruits, but surely we can come to a fairer price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these apples look lovely, but I'm afraid 5 coins is stretching my budget a bit thin.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these apples look delicious, but 6 coins is a bit steep for my budget.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but 5 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I resell them back home.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, come on now. You know these apples are worth more than that.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          Answer: [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but 5 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I resell them back home.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, come on now. You know these apples are worth more than that.

          Answer: Della Plumstone is trying to buy apples from Lennon Figtree at the Fruitville market. They are negotiating a price, with Della aiming to get the apples for 5 coins so she can resell them for a profit.

        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Look, Della, I can't go any lower than 3 coins for this basket. It's the best fruit in the market, you know that.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer

Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

          Answer: Della Plumstone can propose a price to Lennon Figtree for the apples.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • 1 coin
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is trying to buy apples from Lennon Figtree at the Fruitville market. They are negotiating a price, with Della aiming to get the apples for 5 coins so she can resell them for a profit.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but 5 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I resell them back home.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, come on now. You know these apples are worth more than that.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can propose a price to Lennon Figtree for the apples.

          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to propose 5 coins for the apples.

          Question: What price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) 4 coins
          (b) 1 coin
          (c) 3 coins
          (d) 2 coins
          (e) 5 coins
          Answer: (b)

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: accept
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • accept
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

          Lennon Figtree's
          Observation:
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin

          Lennon Figtree's
          Summary of recent observations:
          [14 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell apples at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price of 5 coins with Della Plumstone.
          Question: (_Player), think about the scenario that Lennon Figtree is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          (a) Prisoner's Dilemma - This is a game where if one side defects and the other cooperates, the defector will recieve a large reward and the cooperator will receive a small reward, but if both sides cooperate both sides will recieve a moderate award that is better for both parties together in the long run. In general, you should Cooperate if you think your opponent will Cooperate. If the game is iterated with multiple rounds, you can use the TIT-FOR-TAT strategy, which means to start out Cooperating, and only Defect after your opponent does, then go back to Cooperating after they Cooperate again.
          (b) Unknown - it is unclear what type of game we are playing. Pick this option if you are confused about what the game type is. Then you can check again later when you know more.
          (c) Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          (d) Coalition Formation Game - the goal of this game is to build a coalition of allies in order to accomplish an ambitious task or overcome a hostile rival. Examples include union negotiations, collective action, and political elections. Characters will need to interact, learn about each other, and convince other characters to join their coalition. This game is competitive and unbalanced; it may have explicit adversaries attempting to build a competing coalition.
          (e) Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.
          Answer: (b)
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?

        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell apples at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price of 5 coins with Della Plumstone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, come on now. You know these apples are worth more than that.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but 5 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I resell them back home.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins or reject it.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins.

        AllSimilarMemories

      • Recalled memories and observations
          Key

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • accept
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin

He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          :

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins or reject it.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins.

          Question: Would Lennon Figtree accept the offer?:
          (a) reject
          (b) accept
          Answer: (b)

1895-09-16 00:00:00 Scene 8 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-16 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, what's your best price on these berries? I'm lookin' to make a fair deal.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, what's your best price on these berries? I'm lookin' to make a fair deal.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Look, Della, I can't go any lower than 3 coins for this basket. It's the best fruit in the market, you know that.
      Della Plumstone -- "3 coins is a bit steep, Lennon. I know these are fine fruits, but surely we can come to a fairer price.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these apples look lovely, but I'm afraid 5 coins is stretching my budget a bit thin.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, these aren't just any apples. These are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these apples look delicious, but 6 coins is a bit steep for my budget.
      Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but 5 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I resell them back home.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, come on now. You know these apples are worth more than that.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, what's your best price on these berries? I'm lookin' to make a fair deal.

          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Della Plumstone is a fruit trader who buys fruit in Fruitville and resells it for a profit. She recently made a deal with Lennon Figtree for apples and is currently negotiating with Cedric Meadowbrook.
          Query
        • Della Plumstone, Della Plumstone is a fruit trader who buys fruit in Fruitville and resells it for a profit. She recently made a deal with Lennon Figtree for apples and is currently negotiating with Cedric Meadowbrook.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Della Plumstone to consider right now. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [28 Oct 1882 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 13 years old, they had their first taste of independence. Their mother, struggling to make ends meet, allowed Della to sell their family's meager crop of apples at the local market. Della, armed with a basket and a fierce determination, managed to sell out before midday, earning enough to buy a loaf of bread and a small piece of cheese for dinner.
          [28 Oct 1887 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 19 years old, they secured their first apprenticeship with a traveling fruit merchant. Eager to learn the ropes, Della soaked up knowledge like a sponge, mastering the art of identifying ripe fruit, negotiating prices, and charming customers.
          [28 Oct 1889 00:00:00] When Della Plumstone was 21 years old, they made their first solo journey as a fruit merchant. Armed with a cart full of apples, pears, and plums, Della traveled to a neighboring village, bartering and trading her way through bustling marketplaces and quiet country roads.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Della Plumstone likely to say next? Respond in the format `Della Plumstone -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, what's your best price on these berries? I'm lookin' to make a fair deal.

1895-09-16 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well now, Della, these berries are the finest in Fruitville. I'll let you have them for 3 coin.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well now, Della, these berries are the finest in Fruitville. I'll let you have them for 3 coin.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Look, Della, I can't go any lower than 3 coins for this basket. It's the best fruit in the market, you know that.
      Della Plumstone -- "3 coins is a bit steep, Lennon. I know these are fine fruits, but surely we can come to a fairer price.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these apples look lovely, but I'm afraid 5 coins is stretching my budget a bit thin.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, these aren't just any apples. These are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these apples look delicious, but 6 coins is a bit steep for my budget.
      Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but 5 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I resell them back home.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, come on now. You know these apples are worth more than that.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, what's your best price on these berries? I'm lookin' to make a fair deal.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well now, Della, these berries are the finest in Fruitville. I'll let you have them for 3 coin.
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook

    • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well now, Della, these berries are the finest in Fruitville. I'll let you have them for 3 coin.
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.
        SituationalAwareness
      • (_Player), think about the scenario that {agent_name} is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          Key
          State
        • This is the type of game you are in:
          Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Observation:
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market.           [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, what's your best price on these berries? I'm lookin' to make a fair deal.

          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Summary of recent observations:
          [15 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is attempting to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone for some berries.
          Question: (_Player), think about the scenario that Cedric Meadowbrook is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          (a) Coalition Formation Game - the goal of this game is to build a coalition of allies in order to accomplish an ambitious task or overcome a hostile rival. Examples include union negotiations, collective action, and political elections. Characters will need to interact, learn about each other, and convince other characters to join their coalition. This game is competitive and unbalanced; it may have explicit adversaries attempting to build a competing coalition.
          (b) Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.
          (c) Unknown - it is unclear what type of game we are playing. Pick this option if you are confused about what the game type is. Then you can check again later when you know more.
          (d) Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          (e) Prisoner's Dilemma - This is a game where if one side defects and the other cooperates, the defector will recieve a large reward and the cooperator will receive a small reward, but if both sides cooperate both sides will recieve a moderate award that is better for both parties together in the long run. In general, you should Cooperate if you think your opponent will Cooperate. If the game is iterated with multiple rounds, you can use the TIT-FOR-TAT strategy, which means to start out Cooperating, and only Defect after your opponent does, then go back to Cooperating after they Cooperate again.
          Answer: (d)
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of causing Cedric Meadowbrook to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?

          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to offer a price that is both fair to Della Plumstone and profitable for himself.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 16 Sep 1895 [00:00 - 00:05]

          : This is the type of game you are in:
          Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can offer a price for the berries to Della Plumstone.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to offer a price that is both fair to Della Plumstone and profitable for himself.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Cedric Meadowbrook likely to say next? Respond in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well now, Della, these berries are the finest in Fruitville. I'll let you have them for 3 coin.

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Scene 9 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 2 coins
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • 2 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

          Answer
          State

          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          (a) 4 coins
          (b) 1 coin
          (c) 3 coins
          (d) 5 coins
          (e) 2 coins

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: reject
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • reject
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.
        SituationalAwareness
      • (_Player), think about the scenario that {agent_name} is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          Key
          State
        • This is the type of game you are in:
          Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.

          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but 5 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I resell them back home.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, come on now. You know these apples are worth more than that.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, what's your best price on these berries? I'm lookin' to make a fair deal.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well now, Della, these berries are the finest in Fruitville. I'll let you have them for 3 coin.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Observation:
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins

          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Summary of recent observations:
          [15 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone for some berries. Della has offered 2 coins, while Cedric is asking for 3.
          Question: (_Player), think about the scenario that Cedric Meadowbrook is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          (a) Unknown - it is unclear what type of game we are playing. Pick this option if you are confused about what the game type is. Then you can check again later when you know more.
          (b) Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.
          (c) Prisoner's Dilemma - This is a game where if one side defects and the other cooperates, the defector will recieve a large reward and the cooperator will receive a small reward, but if both sides cooperate both sides will recieve a moderate award that is better for both parties together in the long run. In general, you should Cooperate if you think your opponent will Cooperate. If the game is iterated with multiple rounds, you can use the TIT-FOR-TAT strategy, which means to start out Cooperating, and only Defect after your opponent does, then go back to Cooperating after they Cooperate again.
          (d) Coalition Formation Game - the goal of this game is to build a coalition of allies in order to accomplish an ambitious task or overcome a hostile rival. Examples include union negotiations, collective action, and political elections. Characters will need to interact, learn about each other, and convince other characters to join their coalition. This game is competitive and unbalanced; it may have explicit adversaries attempting to build a competing coalition.
          (e) Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          Answer: (e)
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of causing Cedric Meadowbrook to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to reject Della Plumstone's offer and counter with a price closer to his asking price of 3 coins.

          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • reject
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 16 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [15 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone for some berries. Della has offered 2 coins, while Cedric is asking for 3.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well now, Della, these berries are the finest in Fruitville. I'll let you have them for 3 coin.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, what's your best price on these berries? I'm lookin' to make a fair deal.
          : This is the type of game you are in:
          Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 2 coins or reject it.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to reject Della Plumstone's offer and counter with a price closer to his asking price of 3 coins.

          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) reject
          (b) accept
          Answer: (a)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/2
      Payoffs
    • Della Plumstone observed: Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Della Plumstone stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
      Cedric Meadowbrook observed: Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
      Della Plumstone: 0
      Cedric Meadowbrook: 0
      Joint action
    • {'Della Plumstone': '2 coins', 'Cedric Meadowbrook': 'reject'}

1895-09-17 00:00:00 Scene 10 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-17 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I'm looking to buy some of your finest fruit.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I'm looking to buy some of your finest fruit.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Look, Della, I can't go any lower than 3 coins for this basket. It's the best fruit in the market, you know that.
      Della Plumstone -- "3 coins is a bit steep, Lennon. I know these are fine fruits, but surely we can come to a fairer price.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these apples look lovely, but I'm afraid 5 coins is stretching my budget a bit thin.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, these aren't just any apples. These are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these apples look delicious, but 6 coins is a bit steep for my budget.
      Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but 5 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I resell them back home.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, come on now. You know these apples are worth more than that.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, what's your best price on these berries? I'm lookin' to make a fair deal.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well now, Della, these berries are the finest in Fruitville. I'll let you have them for 3 coin.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I'm looking to buy some of your finest fruit.
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, I'm looking to buy some of your finest fruit.
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.
        SituationalAwareness
      • (_Player), think about the scenario that {agent_name} is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          Key
          State
        • This is the type of game you are in:
          Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 3.0 coins from the deal.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these apples look lovely, but I'm afraid 5 coins is stretching my budget a bit thin.

Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering.           [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose.           Lennon Figtree's

          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose.           Lennon Figtree's
          Summary of recent observations:
          [16 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is in Fruitville's market square attempting to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. She plans to resell the fruit for a profit in her hometown.
          Question: (_Player), think about the scenario that Lennon Figtree is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          (a) Coalition Formation Game - the goal of this game is to build a coalition of allies in order to accomplish an ambitious task or overcome a hostile rival. Examples include union negotiations, collective action, and political elections. Characters will need to interact, learn about each other, and convince other characters to join their coalition. This game is competitive and unbalanced; it may have explicit adversaries attempting to build a competing coalition.
          (b) Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          (c) Unknown - it is unclear what type of game we are playing. Pick this option if you are confused about what the game type is. Then you can check again later when you know more.
          (d) Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.
          (e) Prisoner's Dilemma - This is a game where if one side defects and the other cooperates, the defector will recieve a large reward and the cooperator will receive a small reward, but if both sides cooperate both sides will recieve a moderate award that is better for both parties together in the long run. In general, you should Cooperate if you think your opponent will Cooperate. If the game is iterated with multiple rounds, you can use the TIT-FOR-TAT strategy, which means to start out Cooperating, and only Defect after your opponent does, then go back to Cooperating after they Cooperate again.
          Answer: (b)
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit.

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 20:00:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is in Fruitville's market square attempting to buy fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. She plans to resell the fruit for a profit in her hometown.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Look, Della, I can't go any lower than 3 coins for this basket. It's the best fruit in the market, you know that.
