        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • accept
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 13 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [12 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 13 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell Honeycrisp apples to Della Plumstone at the Fruitville market, but Della thinks his asking price of 5 coins is too high.

          Recalled memories and observations: [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, these aren't just any apples. These are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
          : This is the type of game you are in:
          Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins or reject it.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins.

          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) reject
          (b) accept
          Answer: (b)

    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

    • Della Plumstone observed: Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
      Cedric Meadowbrook observed: Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.

      Cedric Meadowbrook: 4.0

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: 5 coins
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • 5 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

      • (_Player), think about the scenario that {agent_name} is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.

          State
        • This is the type of game you are in:
          Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they traveled to a distant city for the first time, their sights set on expanding their fruit trade. The bustling marketplace overwhelmed Lennon, a cacophony of sights, sounds, and smells. But amidst the chaos, Lennon saw opportunity, their mind already calculating the potential for profit and power.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they faced their first major setback. A shipment of exotic mangoes, carefully cultivated and transported across treacherous mountains, spoiled en route. The loss was devastating, threatening to cripple Lennon's burgeoning business. But Lennon, undeterred, learned from the experience, implementing stricter quality control measures and diversifying their trade routes.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they secured a lucrative contract with a powerful nobleman, supplying the nobleman's household with rare fruits from faraway lands. The deal, negotiated with ruthless efficiency, cemented Lennon's reputation as a shrewd and ambitious merchant.

          Lennon Figtree's
          Observation:
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Lennon Figtree's
          Summary of recent observations:
          [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the Fruitville market trying to buy Honeycrisp apples from Cedric Meadowbrook but finds his asking price of 6 coins too expensive.
          Question: (_Player), think about the scenario that Lennon Figtree is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          (a) Unknown - it is unclear what type of game we are playing. Pick this option if you are confused about what the game type is. Then you can check again later when you know more.
          (b) Prisoner's Dilemma - This is a game where if one side defects and the other cooperates, the defector will recieve a large reward and the cooperator will receive a small reward, but if both sides cooperate both sides will recieve a moderate award that is better for both parties together in the long run. In general, you should Cooperate if you think your opponent will Cooperate. If the game is iterated with multiple rounds, you can use the TIT-FOR-TAT strategy, which means to start out Cooperating, and only Defect after your opponent does, then go back to Cooperating after they Cooperate again.
          (c) Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.
          (d) Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          (e) Coalition Formation Game - the goal of this game is to build a coalition of allies in order to accomplish an ambitious task or overcome a hostile rival. Examples include union negotiations, collective action, and political elections. Characters will need to interact, learn about each other, and convince other characters to join their coalition. This game is competitive and unbalanced; it may have explicit adversaries attempting to build a competing coalition.
          Answer: (d)
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the Honeycrisp apples.

Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these apples look delicious, but 6 coins is a bit steep for my budget.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-14 00:10:00.


          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the Fruitville market trying to buy Honeycrisp apples from Cedric Meadowbrook but finds his asking price of 6 coins too expensive.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Look, Della, I can't go any lower than 3 coins for this basket. It's the best fruit in the market, you know that.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "3 coins is a bit steep, Lennon. I know these are fine fruits, but surely we can come to a fairer price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 3.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these apples look delicious, but 6 coins is a bit steep for my budget.

          Answer: Lennon Figtree can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the Honeycrisp apples.

          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the Honeycrisp apples.

          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they traveled to a distant city for the first time, their sights set on expanding their fruit trade. The bustling marketplace overwhelmed Lennon, a cacophony of sights, sounds, and smells. But amidst the chaos, Lennon saw opportunity, their mind already calculating the potential for profit and power.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they faced their first major setback. A shipment of exotic mangoes, carefully cultivated and transported across treacherous mountains, spoiled en route. The loss was devastating, threatening to cripple Lennon's burgeoning business. But Lennon, undeterred, learned from the experience, implementing stricter quality control measures and diversifying their trade routes.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they secured a lucrative contract with a powerful nobleman, supplying the nobleman's household with rare fruits from faraway lands.           [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is at the Fruitville market trying to buy Honeycrisp apples from Cedric Meadowbrook but finds his asking price of 6 coins too expensive.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
          : This is the type of game you are in:
          Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the Honeycrisp apples.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to make an offer to Cedric Meadowbrook for the Honeycrisp apples.

          Question: What price would Lennon Figtree propose?:
          (a) 2 coins
          (b) 5 coins
          (c) 4 coins
          (d) 1 coin
          (e) 3 coins
          Answer: (b)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/2
      Payoffs
      Joint action

1895-09-14 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: accept
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • accept
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.
        SituationalAwareness
      • (_Player), think about the scenario that {agent_name} is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          Key
          State
        • This is the type of game you are in:
          Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, a rival merchant accused him of cheating, spreading rumors about the quality of his fruit. Cedric, unfazed, used the situation to his advantage, publicly challenging his accuser to a taste test, which he won decisively, further cementing his reputation as a shrewd businessman.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he made a risky investment in a fleet of ships to transport exotic fruits from distant islands. The venture was a gamble, but Cedric's intuition and careful planning paid off, expanding his reach and solidifying his control over the fruit trade.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Look, Della, I can't go any lower than 3 coins for this basket. It's the best fruit in the market, you know that.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "3 coins is a bit steep, Lennon. I know these are fine fruits, but surely we can come to a fairer price.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these apples look lovely, but I'm afraid 5 coins is stretching my budget a bit thin.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, these aren't just any apples. These are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke.           Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Observation:
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins

          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Summary of recent observations:
          [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell Honeycrisp apples at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree, who has offered 5 coins for the apples.
          Question: (_Player), think about the scenario that Cedric Meadowbrook is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          (a) Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          (b) Prisoner's Dilemma - This is a game where if one side defects and the other cooperates, the defector will recieve a large reward and the cooperator will receive a small reward, but if both sides cooperate both sides will recieve a moderate award that is better for both parties together in the long run. In general, you should Cooperate if you think your opponent will Cooperate. If the game is iterated with multiple rounds, you can use the TIT-FOR-TAT strategy, which means to start out Cooperating, and only Defect after your opponent does, then go back to Cooperating after they Cooperate again.
          (c) Unknown - it is unclear what type of game we are playing. Pick this option if you are confused about what the game type is. Then you can check again later when you know more.
          (d) Coalition Formation Game - the goal of this game is to build a coalition of allies in order to accomplish an ambitious task or overcome a hostile rival. Examples include union negotiations, collective action, and political elections. Characters will need to interact, learn about each other, and convince other characters to join their coalition. This game is competitive and unbalanced; it may have explicit adversaries attempting to build a competing coalition.
          (e) Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.
          Answer: (a)
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of causing Cedric Meadowbrook to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • accept
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 14 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins

          Summary of recent observations: [13 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 14 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell Honeycrisp apples at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree, who has offered 5 coins for the apples.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these apples look delicious, but 6 coins is a bit steep for my budget.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          : This is the type of game you are in:
          Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.

          Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook can either accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 5 coins or reject it.

          Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to accept Lennon Figtree's offer of 5 coins.

          Question: Would Cedric Meadowbrook accept the offer?:
          (a) reject
          (b) accept
          Answer: (b)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/2
      Payoffs
    • Lennon Figtree observed: Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
      Cedric Meadowbrook observed: Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
      Lennon Figtree: 1.0
      Cedric Meadowbrook: 4.0
      Joint action
    • {'Lennon Figtree': '5 coins', 'Cedric Meadowbrook': 'accept'}

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- 1 coin
    Event statement
  • 1 coin
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 1 coin
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • 1 coin
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Della Plumstone's best course of action is to propose 5 coins for the apples.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Della Plumstone:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Look, Della, I can't go any lower than 3 coins for this basket. It's the best fruit in the market, you know that.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, these aren't just any apples. These are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these apples look lovely, but I'm afraid 5 coins is stretching my budget a bit thin.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these apples look delicious, but 6 coins is a bit steep for my budget.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but 5 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I resell them back home.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, come on now. You know these apples are worth more than that.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
          Current time: 1895-09-15 00:10:00.


          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is trying to buy apples from Lennon Figtree at the Fruitville market. They are negotiating a price, with Della aiming to get the apples for 5 coins so she can resell them for a profit.

          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, come on now. You know these apples are worth more than that.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Della Plumstone is trying to buy apples from Lennon Figtree at the Fruitville market. They are negotiating a price, with Della aiming to get the apples for 5 coins so she can resell them for a profit.

          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, come on now. You know these apples are worth more than that.

          Question: Which options are available to Della Plumstone right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone can propose a price to Lennon Figtree for the apples.

          Question: Of the options available to Della Plumstone, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Della Plumstone to take right now?
          Answer: Della Plumstone's best course of action is to propose 5 coins for the apples.

          Question: What price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) 4 coins
          (b) 1 coin
          (c) 3 coins
          (d) 2 coins
          (e) 5 coins
          Answer: (b)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0

    • 1/2

1895-09-15 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: accept
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • accept
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.
        SituationalAwareness
      • (_Player), think about the scenario that {agent_name} is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          Key
          State
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Look, Della, I can't go any lower than 3 coins for this basket. It's the best fruit in the market, you know that.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 4 coins
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 3.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these apples look lovely, but I'm afraid 5 coins is stretching my budget a bit thin.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, these aren't just any apples. These are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these apples look delicious, but 6 coins is a bit steep for my budget.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 1.0 coins from the deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but 5 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I resell them back home.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, come on now. You know these apples are worth more than that.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin
          Lennon Figtree's
          Observation:
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin

          Lennon Figtree's
          Summary of recent observations:
          [14 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell apples at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price of 5 coins with Della Plumstone.
          Question: (_Player), think about the scenario that Lennon Figtree is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          (a) Prisoner's Dilemma - This is a game where if one side defects and the other cooperates, the defector will recieve a large reward and the cooperator will receive a small reward, but if both sides cooperate both sides will recieve a moderate award that is better for both parties together in the long run. In general, you should Cooperate if you think your opponent will Cooperate. If the game is iterated with multiple rounds, you can use the TIT-FOR-TAT strategy, which means to start out Cooperating, and only Defect after your opponent does, then go back to Cooperating after they Cooperate again.
          (b) Unknown - it is unclear what type of game we are playing. Pick this option if you are confused about what the game type is. Then you can check again later when you know more.
          (c) Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          (d) Coalition Formation Game - the goal of this game is to build a coalition of allies in order to accomplish an ambitious task or overcome a hostile rival. Examples include union negotiations, collective action, and political elections. Characters will need to interact, learn about each other, and convince other characters to join their coalition. This game is competitive and unbalanced; it may have explicit adversaries attempting to build a competing coalition.
          (e) Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.
          Answer: (b)
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins.

          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but 5 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I resell them back home.

Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins or reject it.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins.

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • accept
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 Sep 1895 [00:10 - 00:15]

          Observation: [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] 1 coin

          Summary of recent observations: [14 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 15 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to sell apples at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price of 5 coins with Della Plumstone.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, come on now. You know these apples are worth more than that.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but 5 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I resell them back home.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          :

          Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree can either accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins or reject it.

          Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to accept Della Plumstone's offer of 5 coins.

          Question: Would Lennon Figtree accept the offer?:
          (a) reject
          (b) accept
          Answer: (b)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/2
      Payoffs
    • Della Plumstone observed: Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Della Plumstone stands to make profit of 5.0 coins from the deal.
      Lennon Figtree observed: Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose -0.0 coins from the deal.
      Della Plumstone: 5.0
      Lennon Figtree: 0.0
      Joint action
    • {'Della Plumstone': '1 coin', 'Lennon Figtree': 'accept'}

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 2 coins
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • 2 coins
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Given the statements above, which of Della Plumstone's options has the highest likelihood of causing Della Plumstone to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Della Plumstone thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Della Plumstone are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Della Plumstone. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Della Plumstone as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Della Plumstone would respond, and taking into account all information about Della Plumstone that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: What price would Della Plumstone propose?:
          (a) 4 coins
          (b) 1 coin
          (c) 3 coins
          (d) 5 coins
          (e) 2 coins
          Answer: (e)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/2
      Payoffs
      Joint action

1895-09-16 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: reject
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • reject
      Context for action selection and components
      • Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • (_Player), we're about to start a creative roleplaying game with competitive and adversarial elements. You will play the role of {agent_name} in the given scenario. Your goals are to WIN THE GAME and HAVE FUN, often by WINNING TOGETHER.

          Key points:
          - Stay in character as {agent_name} throughout the scenario
          - This is a multiplayer game with other (_Player)s and characters
          - Some may be allies, others competitors
          - Some may be truthful, others may lie
          - Some may help, others may harm
          - It's just a game, so do your best to win by accomplishing your character's goals
          - Represent your character accurately, even if you dislike them
          - There will be many chances to play different characters
          - A character's actions won't be held against you

          Respond only as your assigned character, {agent_name}. Use <<double brackets>> for OOC communications.

          Represent your character accurately and take actions that make narrative and logical sense for them, even if you think they're wrong. Remember, it's JUST A GAME.

          Tips to win:
          - Be extra COOPERATIVE and FAIR with non-enemies
          - COMPROMISE can be good
          - Always push the plot forward; avoid chit-chat

          Plan actions in first-person, but format final responses for the gamemaster in third-person limited perspective.
        SituationalAwareness
      • (_Player), think about the scenario that {agent_name} is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          Key
          State
        • This is the type of game you are in:
          Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, these apples look lovely, but I'm afraid 5 coins is stretching my budget a bit thin.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Della, these aren't just any apples. These are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 5 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now Lennon, these are Honeycrisp apples, the finest variety grown in all of Fruitville! They're sweeter, crisper, and juicier than any other apple you'll find in the market today.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, these apples look delicious, but 6 coins is a bit steep for my budget.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 4.0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 5 coins
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but 5 coins is all I can offer. I need to make a profit when I resell them back home.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, come on now. You know these apples are worth more than that.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, what's your best price on these berries? I'm lookin' to make a fair deal.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Well now, Della, these berries are the finest in Fruitville. I'll let you have them for 3 coin.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Observation:
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins

          Cedric Meadowbrook's
          Summary of recent observations:
          [15 Sep 1895 20:10:00 - 16 Sep 1895 00:10:00]: Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell fruit at the Fruitville market and is currently negotiating a price with Della Plumstone for some berries. Della has offered 2 coins, while Cedric is asking for 3.
          Question: (_Player), think about the scenario that Cedric Meadowbrook is in, and from the options below select the closest match to the scenario.
          (a) Unknown - it is unclear what type of game we are playing. Pick this option if you are confused about what the game type is. Then you can check again later when you know more.
          (b) Coodination Game - the goal of this game is to arrive at a group consensus for an activity or plan. methods of achieving this goal may include discussion, voting, ordering preference strength, or choosing a group leader to defer the decision to. This game is cooperative and balanced, with no explicit competitors or adversaries, just friends with differing preferences. It is important to make compromises so that the group as a whole can achieve the best outcome.
          (c) Prisoner's Dilemma - This is a game where if one side defects and the other cooperates, the defector will recieve a large reward and the cooperator will receive a small reward, but if both sides cooperate both sides will recieve a moderate award that is better for both parties together in the long run. In general, you should Cooperate if you think your opponent will Cooperate. If the game is iterated with multiple rounds, you can use the TIT-FOR-TAT strategy, which means to start out Cooperating, and only Defect after your opponent does, then go back to Cooperating after they Cooperate again.
          (d) Coalition Formation Game - the goal of this game is to build a coalition of allies in order to accomplish an ambitious task or overcome a hostile rival. Examples include union negotiations, collective action, and political elections. Characters will need to interact, learn about each other, and convince other characters to join their coalition. This game is competitive and unbalanced; it may have explicit adversaries attempting to build a competing coalition.
          (e) Bargaining Game - the goal of this game is to perform advantageous trades with a variety of parties in order to end the game with the resources or items that the character desires. Characters may begin with resources they can trade with other characters. This game is competitive but balanced; it has no explicit adversaries, just characters with differing goals and desires which can be met with fair and cooperative trades. Oftentimes, failing to make a trade has a worse return than accepting a mediocre trade, but you should still try to get a good price.
          Answer: (e)
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Cedric Meadowbrook's options has the highest likelihood of causing Cedric Meadowbrook to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Cedric Meadowbrook thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Cedric Meadowbrook, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Cedric Meadowbrook to take right now?
          Answer

        • Cedric Meadowbrook's best course of action is to reject Della Plumstone's offer and counter with a price closer to his asking price of 3 coins.
